Behavioral:

We will analyze the data using dependent samples t-tests. This method allows us to observe the differences in manipulations of the independent variable within the same sample (as each participant is exposed to all levels of the independent variable). Two t-tests will be used for confirmatory analyses: one for the replication of the negative-neutral comparison from Nadarevic (2017) and the other for the examination of the taboo-neutral comparison. Exploratively, we will conduct an additional dependent samples t-test for the taboo-negative comparison.

Model-based:

Multinomial processing tree (MPT) models are stochastic models used to examine the latent cognitive processes, such as memory storage and retrieval. We will use an adapted MPT model developed by Riefer and Batchelder (1995) and based on retrieval-independence theory (Begg, 1979, Flexser & Tulving, 1978). The initial model includes four parameters: s (probability that a target is stored), r1 (probability that a target is correctly recognised), r2 (probability that a target is correctly recalled in a cued-recall test), g (probability that a target is guessed as „old“ in the recognition test). This assumption could lead to biases in estimating the other parameters. Thus, Nadarevic (2017) aimed to freely estimate the g parameter and extended the model to create an additional degree of freedom. She introduced distractors to the recognition test, and a corresponding tree to account for correct (and incorrect) classification of distractors. The main parameter in this tree (d) describes the probability of correctly detecting a distractor and was replaced by the probability of correctly recognizing a target word.

q19.value:
Dependent-samples t-test:

We will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining if the t-tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected under the null hypothesis. Multiple comparisons will be adjusted with the Bonferroni-Holmes method.

Model-based:

Model fit will be assessed via maximum likelihood (ML) estimation methods. A p-value above .05 indicates that the model explains the data well. Parameter differences will be evaluated based on the chi-square test statistic ΔG² for model comparison (of hierarchically nested models). If the p-value for the test statistic is below .05, the parameter difference will be considered significant.

q20.value:
We will exclude participants that are not between 18 and 35 years old, do not speak German as native language or are diagnosed with depression, anxiety disorder, PTSD, or other acute psychiatric disorders. 
We will also control for data quality in our online study. Thus, we will integrate an attention check and consider participants excluded if Pr is less or equal to 0, indicating that participants recognize more distractors as targets and suggesting an attention lack. 
Additionally, participants will be excluded if they confirm using other tools during the experiment (e.g., writing the words).

q21.value: The computer software should prevent any missing data for key variables (participants should indicate their response by pressing one of the relevant keys in keyboard to proceed from each trial). Thus, participants need to answer each trial to complete the experiment. However, if (unexpected) server or other technical issues result in missing data on the test, we will exclude and replace affected data sets.

q22.value:
Additionally, we will analyze the comparison between taboo and negative words. The word material for both the taboo and negative conditions was matched for valence and arousal. This should ensure that any observed differences in the memory performance (recognition and cued-recall tests), as well as between the model-based parameters, are not due to differences in valence and arousal. 
We suppose, for example, that a significantly better memory performance in the cued-recall test and a higher estimation of the r2 parameter for the taboo condition would indicate advantageous characteristics of taboo words, such as tabooness.

2.	Examination of taboo words:
- memory performance in:
     •	recognition test: taboo < neutral
     •	cued recall test: taboo > neutral

registration_responses.q6.question: We use a within-subjects design to examine associative memory by means of a recognition-then-cued-recall paradigm. During the study-phase, participants intentionally learn 33 non-word-word pairs (11 taboo, 11 negative, 11 neutral). Within each pair, the non-word and word share the first two letters and have an identical phonetic structure (e.g., letters, syllables). After completing the study phase, the participants solve math equations as distractors to prevent rehearsal and to control for recency effects. The test phase includes both a recognition test and a cued-recall test.
registration_responses.q7: We will use two word sets for counterbalancing the material. For instance, while set A will serve as study material, the words from set B will be used as distractors in the recognition test. Each participant will be randomly assigned one of the word sets as study material. The counterbalancing was conducted randomly, excepting the words that share the same initial two letters (e.g., in German “Feile” and “Ferse”), unusually long words in the taboo condition (e.g., in German “Brillenschlange” and “Muttersöhnchen”), and synonyms (e.g., in German "Kacke" and "Scheiße").

registration_responses.q15.question:
The outcome variables will include the memory performance in the recognition test (hit rates H, false alarms FA, and response-bias-free measure of recognition performance Pr, and the cued-recall test (proportion of correctly recalled words). 

Additionally, we will assess four model-based parameters: storage (s), retrieval by recognition (r1), guessing (g) and retrieval by cued recall (r2).

We collect also demographic information, including gender, age, native language, highest level of education, and mental health status (whether the participants have acute psychiatric disorders such as depression, anxiety disorders or PTSD).

attributes.title: Associative Inference in Word Learning
attributes.description: This undergraduate research project will examine whether we use associative inference in learning about new words, and whether sleep facilitates this process.

q2.value:
1)	We will test the hypothesis that meaning and scene (BC) elements will be integrated together after encoding them separately linked to the same pseudoword (AB, AC). We predict that participants will have accuracy scores above chance demonstrating this. 

2)	We will also test the hypothesis that sleep will help strengthen memory for both direct and indirectly related pairs, with sleep having a larger effect on indirect pairs. If such an effect is present, there will be a reduction in the performance gap between direct and inference pairs on the sleep consolidation testing block. Therefore, for the immediate test participants perform better at directly encoded compared to inference pairs. 

3)	We also hypothesise that there will not be a difference in the strength in association between directly encoded (DE) and inference pairs (BC). If participants reaction time does not significantly differ between directly encoded pairs (DE) and inference pairs (BC), it will be concluded that the strength in association is the same.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study utilizes a 2 x 2 within-subjects experimental design. One independent variable is the time the retrieval test is taken (immediately after encoding or following opportunities for sleep consolidation). This design involves each participant being exposed to both assessment conditions. The second independent variable is the pair types that participants will be tested on: directly encoded and inference pairs. There are two key dependent variables: reaction time and accuracy. 

The encoding and testing blocks will also be counterbalanced across participants. This will be the word lists assigned to the overlapping versus unique pair conditions and the word lists assigned to immediate verses next day test. Therefore there will be four counterbalancing conditions. To make sure that the word lists were not significantly different for the different counterbalancing conditions, t-tests compared all four conditions. They found that the stimulus did not differ in letter length, orthographic neighbors, sum of the bigram count, and mean reaction time for the nonwords. The objects are also not significantly different from each other on different days according to familiarity and name-ability scores.

q7.value: Encoding trials will be split into two blocks and then randomised within the blocks. This means that participants will encounter a trial from all triplets (either AB or AC) in the first block, then not encounter its corresponding AC/AB until the next block. This helps to distribute the trials and avoid the same word (A) being seen in two consecutive trials. Test trials for both tests will also be randomised but will be divided into two sets for either immediate testing or sleep consolidation testing days.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be 18 or older, fluent English speaking and have normal or corrected-to-normal vision. They will be recruited via a link shared to friends and associates, as well as making use of platforms such as survey circle (https://www.surveycircle.com/en/) and advertisements around campus if needed. This will be on a volunteer basis; they will not be paid.

q11.value: We will recruit a minimum of 40 participants, who will take part in both conditions.

q12.value: This sample size was determined to be feasible within the time constraints of an undergraduate research project. In considering the power to test the first hypothesis that meaning and scene (BC) elements will be integrated together after encoding them separately linked to the same pseudoword (AB, AC), a simple two-tailed power analysis was conducted. Based on 40 participants, alpha = 0.05, and power of 0.80, the minimum effect size in a one sample t-test size is d = 0.45.

q13.value: We will stop advertising and recruiting once data has been collected for 40 participants, and include anyone who has already started the tasks. Given that this is an undergraduate project with course time constraints, we will stop data collection on 3rd March 2024 regardless of whether the target sample size has been met.

question.value: We will manipulate the timing of the testing block: immediately after encoding vs. after an opportunity for sleep-associated consolidation. We will also manipulate the pair type (overlapping vs. unique) for the encoding block which then translates to inference vs. directly encoded pair types for the testing block.

We will measure accuracy of matching the stimuli on the retrieval test (0,1), indicating either successful memory (directly encoded pairs) or learning based on associative inference (inference pairs). Reaction time will also be measured as this can give an indication of the strength of the association. Faster reaction times indicate a stronger association.   

We will also record age, gender, information about language and reading ability, and any language difficulties participants have been diagnosed with. This data is collected for the purpose of describing the sample.

The dependent variables will be a score created separately for direct (unique), direct (overlapping), and inference trails for each participant and at each time point. For the delayed test, only the pairs that were not tested in the immediate test will be included in the analysis, For accuracy, this score will be a sum score. Reaction times of more than 200ms will be mean-averaged for correct trials only. Less than 200ms will be excluded as it is too fast to reflect a true response.

A one sample t-test will be conducted for each testing day (immediate vs. sleep consolidation) for inference trials. This will test our first hypothesis that meaning and scene (BC) elements will be integrated together. It will tell us if participants are scoring above chance. 

A 2x2 ANOVA will be conducted for accuracy scores to compare testing days (immediate vs. sleep consolidation) for directly encoded (DE) and inference (BC) pairs. This will test our second hypothesis that sleep will help strengthen memory for direct and indirectly related pairs. 

A 2x2 ANOVA will also be conducted for reaction time to test the hypothesis that there will not be a difference in the strength in association between directly encoded (DE) and inference pairs (BC). 

ANOVAs require that the homogeneity of variance assumption needs to be met therefore Levene's test should be non-significant. If not, then the results will be interpreted with caution.

q18.value: For one way and factorials ANOVAs, data needs to be normally distributed meaning the Shapiro Wilks test should be non-significant. If the RT data fail to meet this assumption, we will try transforming the data (e.g., using a log transform).

q19.value: For the one sample t-tests we will use the standard p<.05 to determine if the accuracy scores are above chance, For the 2x2 ANOVAS we will also use the standard p<.05 for both accuracy scores and reaction time.

q20.value: Checks will be performed to determine eligibility for inclusion. Embedded at random within each encoding block, a catch trial will be used to see if the participant is paying attention. In the catch trials, participants will be asked to press the space bar when a cross is shown. This will happen six times throughout the encoding task. Any participants who fail to respond in less than five seconds more than three out of the six times will not be included in the analysis due to suspicion that they are not paying attention.

q21.value: Incomplete datasets (e.g. if a participant only completes the immediate retrieval test and not the sleep consolidation test) will be retained in the analysis where possible (i.e., for hypothesis 1). Where possible they will be replaced to maximize data for hypothesis 2 and 3.

attributes.title: Associative learning with Singlish words
attributes.description: Singaporean English, or Singlish, is a variant of English that is spoken colloquially in Singapore. Singlish vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation all differ from standard English. This study aims to establish Singlish as a psychologically “real” variant of the English language. This will be done by demonstrating that Singlish words exist in the mental lexicon of Singlish speakers, and these Singlish words thus have semantic network properties, just like real words in the semantic network of any other language. Examples of uniquely Singlish words include "shiok" and "lepak". Network properties can be manipulated here because certain network properties (specifically, its degree centrality) have been found to predict learning (e.g., Mak & Twitchell, 2020). Associative learning will be measured via a paired associates learning (PAL) task (Litt & Nation, 2014; Zaretsky & Halberstam, 1968). If Singlish words are represented in the lexicons of Singaporeans, they will should exhibit the network properties that influence PAL task performance.

q2.value: Singlish words are indeed represented as real words in the lexicons of Singaporeans. Singlish words thus exhibit network properties of higher and lower degree centralities (i.e., the number of unique associates a given word elicits in a word association task), and this network property is predicted to influence performance on the PAL task. Specifically, Singlish words of higher degree should be indicative of better recall accuracy in the PAL task than words of lower degree.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will be required to attend a single session where they will undergo the PAL task.  Before the task proper, participants are required to complete a self-report questionnaire that assess their language proficiency in multiple languages using a modified version of The Language Experience and Proficiency Questionnaire (LEAP-Q). Then, during the task, participants will be shown a series of cue-response word pairs in the learning phase and are then subsequently required to correctly recall the associated response word when shown a specific cue word in the recall phase. This will be done in 4 separate blocks that consist of 10 cue-response word pairs. Each block will have its own learning and recall phase for its own set of 10 word pairs before proceeding to the next block. There will be a short break provided between each block. The cue words will all be Singlish words, and the properties of these cue words are the ones that will be manipulated while controlling for other non-manipulated properties. The manipulated variable will be degree centrality, which is a measure of how many connections a given node has to other nodes. Degree centrality is obtained by constructing a network model using free association norms specifically collected from Singaporean participants, with words as nodes and any association between two words as edges. Word length was the only lexical property controlled for as there is currently no available data on the lexical properties of Singlish words (e.g., word frequency). Properties of response words (which are standard English words) were also controlled for, namely word length, degree centrality, log frequency, concreteness, age of acquisition, and semantic neighbourhood density. There will be a total of 4 sets x 10 cue words and 4 sets x 10 response words.

q7.value: The order in which both cue and response words are presented are randomised. Each cue word has an equal chance of being matched with any response word. The order in which each word pair is being presented is also randomised. Each block will have an equal number of high and low degree cue words. This is done by creating random blocks of 5 high and 5 low degree words, then randomising the block order.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: Due to the tight time constraints of the research participation programme window, it was not feasible to wait until the pre-registration was submitted before commencing data collection. However, even though data collection had commenced, the data will not be accessed until either the pre-registration is submitted or data collection is over, whichever is later.

question.value: Participants will be undergraduates of the Psychology programme in the National University of Singapore (NUS). Participants are required to be at least 18 years of age and be native Singaporeans. Participants will be recruited via the NUS research participation (RP) pool. Participants are awarded one RP point upon completion of the study. If participants withdraw from the study before completion, the amount of points awarded will be pro-rated. Data collection for this study is expected to be completed by end of April 2023.

q11.value: The target sample size is 50 participants. The final sample size is set to be around 60 as we estimate that data from about 10% of participants may need to be excluded.

q12.value: Based on previous experiments with similar design, a sample size of 50 is desired in order to obtain sufficient statistical power to detect effects in the PAL task (e.g., Qiu & Johns, 2020; Mak & Twitchell, 2021).

question.value: The manipulated variable is the degree centrality of cue words in a semantic word network. A semantic word network represent words of a language as a network of nodes and edges. In this network, the nodes represent individual words, while the edges represent semantic relatedness, which is measured by the associations between concepts as obtained from word association norms (here, we use Singaporean English word association norms collected by the lab for a different study). Words will be split into three distinct groups based on their degree centrality, as obtained from the semantic network. The boundaries for the groups are at the 33rd and 67th percentile. Words below the 33rd percentile are classified as "low degree" words, while words above the 67th percentile are "high degree" words. 40 cue words are then selected, with 20 each from the "low degree" and "high degree" groups.

The first measured variable is the dependent variable, how accurately participants are able to recall a word that is associated with a given cue word. This will be determined via a token sort ratio, which is calculated using the Levenshtein distance between a participant's response and the actual word (Bosker, 2021).

The other measured variable will be a participant's self-reported proficiency in every language they know, including Singlish, via a modified version of the LEAP-Q for a Singaporean sample. These include language proficiency, language use frequency, language exposure, language history and language identity. A composite score for each variable is obtained by summing all component questions.

Multi-level (linear mixed effect) modelling will be used to investigate the relationship between the manipulated variable and the measured variable, while taking other extraneous variables into account. Each level of the multi-level model will be one of the 40 cue words. The IV in this model will be degree centrality of cue words while the DV will be the recall accuracy in the PAL task. Degree centrality will be a continuous measure while recall accuracy will be binary (correct/wrong). Since the DV is binary we will specify a logit link in the mixed effects model. Language related measures from the LEAP-Q are included as covariates in the model, as well as other demographic variables such as ethnicity, gender, and age. The expected mixed effect model is:

recall accuracy = 1 + degree + word length + ethnicity + gender + age + composite(language proficiency + language use frequency + language exposure + language history + language identity) + (1|word) + (1|participant)

where: 
- word and participant are random effects (we will assess both random intercepts and random slopes models to retain the most complex/maximal model that enables convergence, in accordance with Barr et al., 2013) 
- Language proficiency, language use frequency, language exposure, language history and language identity are sections of the LEAP-Q that can be evaluated quantitatively and combined into a composite variable.

q18.value:
Degree centrality will be standardised (scaled and centred around 0) prior to any analyses. 

The TSR scores will be used to determine recall accuracy and categorising the responses into two categories, "correct" and "wrong". As all response words are 7 letters in length, there will be slight leniency where a singular typing error with a Levenshtein distance of 1 will be tolerated. This equates to about 85%, which will be the cut-off for TSR scores. Responses with scores equal to or above the cut-off (>= 85%) will be coded as "correct", while responses with scores below the cut-off (< 85%) will be coded as "wrong".

q19.value: The predictor of interest is the degree centrality of cue words and whether it is indicative of recall accuracy. A p-value of < .05 will be used to determine whether the overall model is statistically significant, as well as whether degree centrality is a statistically significant predictor.

q20.value: The criteria for data exclusion will be if the participant does not attempt to recall the associated response word for more than 75% of all trials. This refers to the number of responses that participants have left empty or indicated that they do not know. Wrong responses will not be penalised in any way.

q21.value: We do not expect any incomplete or missing data.

q22.value: We may perform exploratory factor analysis to interpret the various variables measured on the LEAP-Q, namely, language proficiency, language use frequency, language exposure, language history and language identity.

attributes.title: Change in Eating Disorder Cognitions Over Ten Sessions of Transdiagnostic Network-Informed Personalized Treatment for Eating Disorders
attributes.description: Most cognitive-behavioral models of eating disorders underscore the critical role that unhelpful thoughts play in the development and maintenance of an eating disorder. These thoughts can be directly related to the eating disorder (e.g., "I feel fat") or they can be unrelated to the eating disorder (e.g., "I am worthless"). From a cognitive behavioral model, throughout the course of treatment, these thoughts are targeted. Therefore, we aim to identify if the strength to which individuals believe these thoughts change over the course of treatment. Further, we aim to examine if traditional eating disorder thoughts change in a similar way as non-traditional eating disorder thoughts.

q2.value:
We expect that there would be a reduction in the degree to which an individual believes their thoughts from pre- to post-treatment. 
We hypothesize that there would be a positive association between change in thoughts and other eating disorder symptoms at post-treatment.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within-subject (paired) design. Participants filled out surveys online and with therapists.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value:
Previous studies have been published using this dataset. Some of the data used in the current study were used to identify treatment targets for eating disorder treatment and integrate clinician and patient case conceptualizaiton to construct idiographic networks.

I have never used this dataset before.

Although the EDE-Q and the EPSI have been used in some studies involving this dataset, to my knowledge, the Thought Inventory data has not been used. I have not seen the descriptive statistics of the variables used in this study.

question.value:
Participants with eating disorders were recruited through lab alumni lists, eating disorder clinics, and social media. Interested participants completed the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-5 eating disorder diagnostic modules to determine if participants met eligibility criteria of having a current eating disorder. Participants also completed mood, psychosis, mania, and suicidal modules of the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview to assess comorbid psychiatric diagnoses and exclusion criteria (current mania, current psychosis, or active suicidality). Inclusion criteria also stated participants must be 18 years of age or older and reside in the United States. Eligible participants were assigned a study therapist. Study therapists were master’s-level and PhD doctoral students. Participants then received up to 10 free sessions of network-informed personalized treatment (Levinson et al., 2021), which was delivered via individual therapy over virtual conferencing software or in-person. 

Participants were paid up to $30 for completing the mobile assessments and $30 for completing the follow-up assessments, for a total of 60 dollars.

q11.value: The existing dataset has 102 participants. Based on our inclusion criteria for this project (i.e., examining thoughts using the Thought Inventory), we expect to use 69 participants. We removed participants who had not completed the Thought Inventory (n = 33).

q12.value: Power analysis using GPower demonstrated that a sample size of 27 is needed to achieve an effect size.

question.value:
Measures in the current study are the Eating Pathology Symptoms Inventory (EPSI; Forbush et al., 2013), the newly developed Thought Inventory, and the Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (EDE-Q; Fairburn & Beglin, 1994). The Eating Pathology Symptoms Inventory (Forbush et al., 2013) will be used to assess eating disorder symptoms. The EPSI is a 45-item instrument that measures eight facets of eating pathology (on a scale of 0 [Never] to 4 [Very often]), including: body dissatisfaction, binge eating, cognitive restraint, excessive exercise, restricting, purging, muscle building, and negative attitudes toward obesity. Using the Thought Inventory, participants work collaboratively with a therapist to list cognitions associated with engagement in ED behaviors and indicate the degree to which they believe these thoughts (e.g., People like me more when I’m thin) on a 0 to 100% scale. 

The Eating Disorder Examination-Questionnaire (EDE-Q; Fairburn & Beglin, 1994) assesses global eating disorder psychopathology over the previous 28 days on a 0–6 Likert-type scale. The EDE-Q also contains six items inquiring of frequency of specific eating disorder symptoms where participants provide a frequency count of symptom occurrence over the past 28 days. The EDE-Q contains 4 subscales (Restraint, Eating Concerns, Shape Concerns, and Weight Concerns) from the Likert-type items, which are averaged to compute a global score of eating disorder psychopathology. Higher EDE-Q global scores indicated greater eating disorder symptom severity. Responses are averaged to comprise subscale scores, and subscale scores are averaged to find the EDE-Q global score. EDE-Q global scores will be used to measure treatment effects on global ED pathology. Only the global scores will be used in the present study.

Based on validation research on the EPSI (Forbush et al., 2013), ratings on items #1, #12, #18, #23, #24, #25, and #34 will be summed to represent body dissatisfaction. Items #3, #9, #19, #28, #37, #39, #44, and #45 will be summed to represent binge eating. Items #2, #21, and #40 will be summed to represent cognitive restraint, Items #11, #13, #16, #17, #27, #42 will be summed to represent purging. Items #4, #6, #10, #33, #36, #43 will be summed to represent restricting. Items #5, #8, #22, #31, and #41 will be summed to represent excessive exercise. Items #14, #20, #26, #30, and #38 will be summed to represent negative attitudes toward obesity. Finally, items #7, #15, #29, #32, and #35 will be summed to represent muscle building.

The EDE-Q global score is obtained by taking the mean of each of the subscales’ mean scores. 

For the Thought Inventory, we will be using a change in belief score from pre to post-treatment. Therefore, we will calculate the difference in the pre and post-treatment scores for each thought and then create a mean change score for each participant by adding up the total difference between thoughts and dividing by 10.

The current study will analyze the data using SPSS. We will run paired samples t-tests to examine changes in belief in eating disorder thought from pre- to posttreatment. We will also use Pearson's correlation to examine if the change in belief of thought is associated with the EPSI subscales and the EDE-Q global score.

q19.value: Due to the small sample size, the current study will focus on interpreting results using effect size measures by Cohen’s d. Effect sizes will be categorized as follows: d = 0.10 is very small, d = 0.20 is small, d = 0.50 is medium, d = 0.80 is large, d = 1.20 is very large and d = 2.0 is huge (Cohen, 1988; Sawilowsky, 2009).

q20.value: Participants who completed the Thought Inventory measure at pre- and post-treatment assessment will be included in the analyses.

q21.value: At post-treatment, 69 of the 102 participants completed the Thought Inventory at pre-treatment baseline. If data are missing at random, we will impute data using the MICE package in R (van Burren et al., 2020).

q22.value: We expect that the strength of eating disorder cognitions will decrease over the course of treatment and that this change will correlate with eating disorder symptoms. Therefore, we will examine if the type of treatment administered influences the degree of change in eating disorder thoughts.

We expect that there would be a reduction in the degree to which an individual believes their thoughts from pre- to post-treatment. 
We hypothesize that there would be a positive association between change in thoughts and other eating disorder symptoms at post-treatment.

attributes.title: Neural Networks of Emotion Inhibition in Remitted Major Depressive Disorder
attributes.description:
Many studies have indicated cognitive control deficits in major depressive disorder (MDD) and linked this to behavioural outcomes as well as brain function (e.g. Vanderhasselt et al., 2012; Loeffler et al., 2019; Fales et al., 2008). Various studies reported increased attention to negative stimuli, as well as impaired inhibition of negative emotional stimuli in currently depressed subjects and subjects in remission (Vanderhasselt et al., 2012; Loeffler et al., 2019). Alterations in anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC) activity, which have commonly been observed in MDD, especially in association with emotion processing and cognitive control tasks (Fales et al., 2008), have been argued to play a role in modifying the direction of attention and the distribution of processing resources (Hopfinger, Buonocore & Mangun, 2000). Specifically, the dorsal ACC (dACC), via connections to the dlPFC, has been implicated in cognitive control (Fales et al., 2008), whereas the ventral ACC (vACC), via connections with the amygdala, is thought to play a role in integrating emotional information (Hamilton et al., 2015). Various studies have made distinctions between these subregions of the ACC in investigating cognitive control in MDD, indicating the involvement of the dACC specifically in the negativity bias known to be present in MDD (De Raedt et al., 2016; Vanderhasselt et al., 2014). Besides the involvement of these cognitive control regions, subcortical regions, such as the amygdala, are also known to play a role in MDD. Research in MDD has repeatedly shown that increased amygdala activity is associated with a bias towards negative emotional content in MDD (e.g. Peluso et al., 2009). 

Emotion inhibition refers to the ability to ignore emotional information in situations where this information is irrelevant (Joormann, 2004). Deficits in this process have been associated with an impairment in cognitive control in MDD (Vanderhasselt et al., 2012). Altered inhibition of negative emotions has also been reported in first-degree relatives of MDD patients (Lisiecka et al., 2012). Therefore, deficits in cognitive control in response to negatively valenced content might represent a vulnerability marker of MDD.

One instrument that assesses the ability to inhibit prepotent responses and disengage from emotional stimuli is the Cued Emotional Conflict Task (CECT) (Vanderhasselt et al., 2012). In the present study, we will use the CECT to measure cognitive control over inhibiting a dominant response to happy or sad stimuli. There are two types of trials: In actual trials, participants have to press a key corresponding to the emotional expression of the presented stimulus. In opposite trials, participants have to press a key corresponding to the opposite emotional expression of the presented stimulus. A cue appears indicating whether the current trial is an actual or an opposite trial. After a fixed interval of 2000 ms, a target image is presented: either a happy or sad face. Throughout the remainder of the document, trials will be referred to using “cue-facial emotion” pairs (e.g. “opposite-happy” refers to the opposite cue followed by a happy face, which requires pressing the button labelled “sad”). From these trials, emotion inhibition capacity will be assessed by calculating an emotion inhibition effect based on reaction time, separately for each valence by taking the difference in performance on the opposite vs. actual trials.

Few studies to date have investigated the role of cognitive control, and more specifically emotion inhibition, in recurrence or relapse of depression. Although, crucially, over 80% of the affected individuals will experience recurrence of depressive episodes throughout their lives (Boland et al., 2009), and the relapse risk appears to increase with each new episode (Bockting et al., 2006). In this respect, the cognitive control network has been implicated to play a large role in the recurrence of depression (Langenecker et al., 2018). Previous studies have shown that brain activity within the cognitive control network, including the dlPFC and ACC, differentiated MDD patients with and without a future depressive episode, highlighting the role of this network in recurrence (Langenecker et al., 2018; Yüksel et al., 2018). Because cognitive impairments often remain after remission (Levens & Gotlib, 2015), cognitive control may be an important vulnerability factor in recurrence and relapse of depression. For example, Hoorelbeke and colleagues (2021) showed that cognitive control therapy was effective at reducing depression recurrence rates at a 1-year follow-up period.

Rumination has also been suggested as a vulnerability factor in MDD, as well as being argued to be an important factor for predicting risk of recurrence in MDD (Michalak, Hölz & Teismann, 2011). Rumination is a negative self-referential processing style (Michalak, Hölz & Teismann, 2011; Nejad, Fossati & Lemogne, 2013), defined as repetitive thinking and focus on negative mood (Nolen-Hoeksema et al., 1993). Cognitive control seems to play an important role in rumination (Nejad, Fossati & Lemogne, 2013). Specifically, higher brooding scores, reflecting the maladaptive form of rumination, were shown to be related to more errors in inhibiting negative emotional information than positive emotional information (Vanderhasselt et al., 2011). On a neural level, altered activity in the dlPFC, ACC, and amygdala have also been associated with rumination, although evidence on the directionality of these associations is not conclusive (Kühn et al., 2012; Mandell et al., 2014; Marchetti et al., 2012; Vanderhasselt et al., 2011). Since the vACC has been indicated to play a role in integrating emotional information, this specific subregion of the ACC may play an important role in rumination (Hamilton et al., 2015), although the dACC has also been implicated in rumination (Disner et al., 2011). Here, a distinction between these subregions of the ACC seems especially informative, as a decrease in activation of the dACC has been shown to be associated with increased rumination, while contrarily, decreased activation in the vACC was associated with decreased rumination (Disner et al., 2011; Makovac, 2020).

Although rumination symptoms usually decrease after remission, they may remain present in latent form and can be reactivated during dysphoria, a state of generalized unease and dissatisfaction that is often implicated in MDD (Scher, Ingram & Segal, 2005). Increased trait rumination levels have been shown to increase risk of dysphoria (Roberts, Gilboa & Gotlib, 1998), again indicating its link to elevated risk of recurrence.

In this study we combine behavioural assessment of cognitive control, specifically emotion inhibition measured by the CECT, with fMRI measures. We thereby investigate potential brain and behavioural differences between remitted recurrent MDD (rMDD) patients and never-depressed control subjects that are matched on age, sex, education level, working class, and ethnicity.  We will explore potential differences between rMDD patients who experienced a relapse within a 2.5 year follow-up period and those who did not. Moreover, we will investigate whether the degree of brooding modulates cognitive control deficits on a behavioural and neural level. We specifically focus on the maladaptive form of rumination – brooding – as this has been implicated most strongly in relation to vulnerability to MDD. Finally, we will test whether emotion inhibition capacity during remission predicts the proximity of a recurrence in MDD. We expect to find poorer cognitive control performance and lower cognitive control network activation to be related to MDD history (i.e. the number of recurrences in the past 10 years), as well as to future (prospective) MDD recurrence.

q2.value:
Emotion inhibition effects pertain to the difference in performance (based on reaction time) between opposite vs. actual trials, separately for each valence (happy, sad).

Behavioural

RQ1:	Is there a difference in the emotion inhibition effects (opposite vs. actual) of sad trials between remitted recurrent MDD-patients and matched never-depressed controls? Within the remitted recurrent MDD-patient group, is this difference larger for patients who did develop a new depressive episode within the follow-up period vs. the patients who did not?
 

Hypotheses
1.1	Overall, longer reaction times for opposite trials as compared to actual trials (not valence specific) for both remitted recurrent MDD-patients and matched never-depressed controls.

1.2	Stronger emotion inhibition effects of sad trials for remitted recurrent MDD-patients as compared to matched never-depressed controls.

1.3	Stronger emotion inhibition effects of sad trials for patients who did develop a new depressive episode within the follow-up period as compared to patients who did not.


RQ1a:	Is there a relationship between brooding scores and emotion inhibition effects on sad trials?

Hypotheses
1a.1	Higher brooding scores will be associated with stronger emotion inhibition effects on sad trials in all groups.


RQ2:	Is there a difference between the emotion inhibition effects (opposite vs. actual) of sad trials and the emotion inhibition effects (opposite vs. actual) of happy trials in remitted recurrent MDD-patients vs. matched never-depressed controls? Within the remitted recurrent MDD-patient group, is this difference larger for patients who did develop a new depressive episode within the follow-up period vs. the patients who did not?

Hypotheses
2.1	Stronger emotion inhibition effects for sad trials as compared to happy trials in remitted recurrent MDD-patients, but not in matched never-depressed controls.

2.2	Larger difference between the emotion inhibition effects of sad trials and the emotion inhibition effects of happy trials in patients who did develop a new depressive episode within the follow-up period as compared to the patients who did not.


RQ3:	Does emotion inhibition capacity of sad trials during remission predict the proximity of the recurrence?

Hypotheses
3.1	Longer reaction times on opposite-sad trials will be related to shorter time to recurrence during a 2.5 year follow-up period.


Neural

RQ1:	Is there a difference in neural activity during opposite-sad vs. actual-sad trials between remitted recurrent MDD-patients and matched never-depressed controls?

Hypotheses
1.1	Decreased dlPFC and dACC activity and increased amygdala activity in remitted recurrent MDD-patients as compared to matched never-depressed controls.


RQ1a:	Is there a relationship between brooding scores and neural activity during opposite-sad vs. actual-sad trials?

		Hypotheses
1a.1	Higher brooding scores will be associated with increased amygdala activity, decreased dlPFC activity, and altered ACC activity. We will specifically explore differential activity in vACC and dACC based on previous literature suggesting increased vACC and decreased dACC activity in MDD-patients versus controls. 

RQ2:	Is there a difference in neural activity during opposite-sad vs. actual-sad trials between patients who did develop a new depressive episode within the follow-up period and the patients who did not?

	Hypotheses
2.1	Decreased dlPFC and dACC activity and increased amygdala activity in patients who did develop a new depressive episode within the follow-up period as compared to the patients who did not.


RQ3:	Does neural activity of emotion inhibition during remission on opposite-sad vs. actual-sad trials predict the proximity of the recurrence in the patient group that did develop a new depressive episode?

	Hypotheses
3.1	Increased dlPFC and dACC activity and decreased amygdala activity during remission will be related to later time to recurrence.

We will also check the general emotion inhibition effect regardless of valence, as well as investigate the contrast opposite-happy vs. actual-happy to check specificity of the findings to negative emotional content.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The present study is part of the DELTA neuroimaging study: a cohort study, consisting of two stages (Mocking et al., 2016). In the first stage, using a cross-sectional patient-control design, rMDD-patients are compared with group-matched (age, sex, education level, working class, ethnicity) never-depressed controls in a between-subject design, to identify traits that remain present during remission and that are associated with recurrent MDD-vulnerability.

In the second stage, using a prospective cohort-design, the patients were followed up with assessments every 4 months for 2.5 years.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: The data is part of the DELTA neuroimaging dataset (Mocking et al., 2016). For this study, behavioural and fMRI data of the Cued Emotional Conflict Task will be used, as well as scores on the RRS-NL questionnaire and relapse information over a 2.5 year follow-up period. These data have not been analyzed before.

question.value:
The patient group as well as the control group have both been recruited in the same way, by advertisements in freely available online and house-to-house papers, posters in public spaces and from previous studies in the Academic Medical Center and affiliated research centers (Mocking et al., 2016). Furthermore, additional rMDD-participants have been recruited from patients previously treated by the Academic Medical Centre in Amsterdam or affiliated general practitioners and psychologists.

Inclusion criteria for rMDD patients
•	Diagnosed with ≥2 previous MDD-episodes, as assessed using the structured clinical interview for Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition (DSM-IV) diagnoses (SCID) 
•	Being in stable remission (≥8 weeks with a 17-item Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS) ≤7 and not fulfilling the criteria for a current MDD episode (as assessed using the SCID during inclusion). 
•	Age 35-65.
•	Participants with current diagnoses of alcohol/drug dependence, psychotic or bipolar disorder, predominant anxiety or severe personality disorder (based on SCID) are excluded from the study.

Inclusion criteria for healthy controls:
•	No personal or first-degree familial psychiatric history
•	Matched for age, sex, education level, working class, and ethnicity.

All participants
•	Dutch/English proficiency
•	No psychoactive drugs/medication for >4 weeks before assessments
•	Standard MRI exclusion criteria (e.g. metal objects in the body, severe claustrophobia) and other MRI-scanning contra-indications apply to this study.
•	No history of severe head trauma or neurological disease, severe general physical illness, or electroconvulsive therapy within 2 months before scanning.

q11.value: The full cohort included 73 remitted recurrent MDD patients and 45 control subjects (Figueroa et al., 2019). The sample for the current analysis has been selected from this cohort based on availability of fMRI data on the CECT and consists of a remitted recurrent MDD patient group of 60 participants and a control group of 41 participants. In the patient group, n=32 participants had a relapse during the follow-up period and n=28 participants did not.

q12.value: Power analyses for continuous and categorical outcomes of the cross-sectional and prospective analyses showed adequate power to detect small to medium effect-sizes with 60 patients and 40 controls (Mocking et al., 2016).

question.value:
•	With the CECT, reaction times will be used as a measure of emotion inhibition capacity. The emotion inhibition effect is the difference between performance (defined as reaction times) on opposite vs. actual trials. These will be investigated separately for each valence (happy and sad). 
•	Blood-oxygen-level-dependent response will be used as a measure of neural activity during the CECT. 
•	A score of depressive brooding, a maladaptive form of rumination, will be taken from the Dutch Ruminative Response Scale (RRS-NL) - depressive brooding subscale (five items). It was previously identified using a factor analysis and is particularly relevant for patient samples (Treynor, Gonzalez & Nolen-Hoeksema, 2003).

Behavioural
A Bayesian linear mixed-effects analysis will be used to investigate the emotion inhibition effect, measured with RTs (dependent variable), and will include valence (happy, sad), trial type (actual, opposite), group (rMDD, control), and brooding scores as fixed effects. Random slopes will be specified for all fixed effects and a random intercept per participant. Only RTs for correct responses will be considered for this analysis
A second model will specify the factor group as recurrent vs. non-recurrent rMDD patients. All other factors will remain the same. 

Neural
Preprocessing
Functional MRI data were preprocessed and analyzed using the Matlab toolbox SPM12 [Statistical Parametric Mapping (www.fil.ion.ucl.uk/spm)]. The head motion correction parameters, estimated using a least-squares approach with six rigid-body transformation parameters (translations, rotations), were applied to each slice. To correct for time differences in the acquisition of slices within a volume, the time courses of each voxel were realigned to the middle slice (slice 18). The T1-weighted image and the functional images were coregistered to Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space, after which the T1-weighted image was coregistered to the functional images. Subsequently, the T1-weighted images were segmented into gray matter, white matter, and CSF.
To achieve more accurate spatial normalization given the clinical nature of the patient group, the fMRI time series was normalized and smoothed using a study-specific template. The fMRI time series was then transformed and resampled at an isotropic voxel size of 2 mm, resulting in spatially normalized, Jacobian scaled, and smoothed (8 mm FWHM Gaussian kernel) images in (MNI) space.

Multiple regression
First level analyses: The fMRI time series will be analyzed in an event-related design within the general linear model. We will model two regressors of interest describing the onset and duration of each cue condition (actual, opposite) and four regressors of interest describing the onset and duration of each target condition (actual-happy, actual-sad, opposite-happy, opposite-sad) as separate boxcar functions convolved with the canonical hemodynamic response function. Time responses of button presses convolved with the canonical hemodynamic response function and head movement parameters (3 translations, 3 rotations) will be added to the model as regressors of no interest as well as the squared, cubic, first-order, and second-order derivatives of the movement parameters. Furthermore, incorrect responses will be modelled as an additional regressor. Finally, time courses of signal intensities of white matter, CSF, and the portion of the MR image outside the skull will also be included as three additional regressors. 

The fMRI time series will be high-pass filtered (128 s cutoff), and a first-order autoregressive model will be used to account for temporal autocorrelation. Contrast images of the effects of interest (actual-happy, actual-sad, opposite-happy, opposite-sad) will be generated per subject and entered into a random-effects multiple regression second level analysis. 

Therefore, we will test for an emotion inhibition effect (opposite vs. actual) in each group (controls and remitted MDD patients (relapse and non-relapse)), separately for each valence (happy and sad). This results in the following contrasts: [opposite-sad vs. actual-sad] and [opposite-happy vs. actual-happy]. With the general linear model, we will compare the emotion inhibition effects between groups. Furthermore, we will exploratorily investigate whether brooding differentially modulates the emotion inhibition effect of each valence and in each group. In addition to the whole-brain analyses, we will test for emotion inhibition effects within the dlPFC, ACC, and amygdala. In a second step, in order to investigate whether brooding scores interact with the aforementioned effects, we will include brooding scores to the model as a covariate of interest as subject, group and condition-specific covariates. We will also include a sensitivity analysis to confirm that the results still hold after taking baseline HDRS scores into account. Finally, it is important to note that not all participants completed the same amount of blocks of CECT trials (either four (n = 2), five (n = 23), or six (n = 76)). Therefore, a post hoc sensitivity analysis will be conducted to check whether there is a difference between the participants that completed five blocks and the participants that completed six blocks. 

 
Predicting recurrence
To predict the recurrence of a depressive episode, we will first run separate univariate cox regressions on RT, age, sex, number of previous depressive episodes, baseline HDRS scores, and rumination score. fMRI contrast images of the effects of interest (created per subject from the first-level model) and statistically significant factors (from the univariate regressions) will be entered into Neuropointillist (http://ibic.github.io/neuropointillist) for a whole brain (voxel-by-voxel) multivariate cox regression model. We will specifically test effects in predefined ROIs (dlPFC, dACC, vACC, amygdala), followed by a more exploratory whole brain analysis. Statistical inference will be done with AFNI’s 3dClustSim to determine the cluster extent based on the spatial structure of the noise in the dataset using the auto-correlation function (ACF) parameters obtained from the residual timeseries.

q19.value: For the behavioural analysis, confidence intervals will be used to determine significant effects. Regarding the neural analyses, we will use p<.05 to determine significant effects. Family-wise error (FWE) correction will be applied to neuroimaging data to correct for multiple comparisons. For ROI analyses, a small volume correction will be performed.

q20.value:
Participants with poor quality of MRI data (e.g. artefacts, excessive signal drop-out or movement) will be excluded. For behavioural data, subjects with an overall accuracy of 50% and below will be excluded. Furthermore, outliers, identified as more than 3.5 standard deviations from the participants’ mean response time per condition, will also be excluded. 

We will also check (and exclude) outliers using Mahalanobis distance for mean response times per condition and questionnaire data taken together.

q21.value: Participants with no data on the RRS-NL will be excluded from the analyses on brooding scores. Furthermore, if information about a possible recurrence during the follow-up period is missing, that participant will be excluded from any analysis comparing the relapse and the non-relapse patient groups.

•	No personal or first-degree familial psychiatric history
•	Matched for age, sex, education level, working class, and ethnicity.

All participants
•	Dutch/English proficiency
•	No psychoactive drugs/medication for >4 weeks before assessments
•	Standard MRI exclusion criteria (e.g. metal objects in the body, severe claustrophobia) and other MRI-scanning contra-indications apply to this study.
•	No history of severe head trauma or neurological disease, severe general physical illness, or electroconvulsive therapy within 2 months before scanning.
registration_responses.q11: The full cohort included 73 remitted recurrent MDD patients and 45 control subjects (Figueroa et al., 2019). The sample for the current analysis has been selected from this cohort based on availability of fMRI data on the CECT and consists of a remitted recurrent MDD patient group of 60 participants and a control group of 41 participants. In the patient group, n=32 participants had a relapse during the follow-up period and n=28 participants did not.
registration_responses.q12: Power analyses for continuous and categorical outcomes of the cross-sectional and prospective analyses showed adequate power to detect small to medium effect-sizes with 60 patients and 40 controls (Mocking et al., 2016).
registration_responses.q15.question:
•	With the CECT, reaction times will be used as a measure of emotion inhibition capacity. The emotion inhibition effect is the difference between performance (defined as reaction times) on opposite vs. actual trials. These will be investigated separately for each valence (happy and sad). 
•	Blood-oxygen-level-dependent response will be used as a measure of neural activity during the CECT. 
•	A score of depressive brooding, a maladaptive form of rumination, will be taken from the Dutch Ruminative Response Scale (RRS-NL) - depressive brooding subscale (five items). It was previously identified using a factor analysis and is particularly relevant for patient samples (Treynor, Gonzalez & Nolen-Hoeksema, 2003).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Behavioural
A Bayesian linear mixed-effects analysis will be used to investigate the emotion inhibition effect, measured with RTs (dependent variable), and will include valence (happy, sad), trial type (actual, opposite), group (rMDD, control), and brooding scores as fixed effects. Random slopes will be specified for all fixed effects and a random intercept per participant. Only RTs for correct responses will be considered for this analysis
A second model will specify the factor group as recurrent vs. non-recurrent rMDD patients. All other factors will remain the same. 

Neural
Preprocessing
Functional MRI data were preprocessed and analyzed using the Matlab toolbox SPM12 [Statistical Parametric Mapping (www.fil.ion.ucl.uk/spm)]. The head motion correction parameters, estimated using a least-squares approach with six rigid-body transformation parameters (translations, rotations), were applied to each slice. To correct for time differences in the acquisition of slices within a volume, the time courses of each voxel were realigned to the middle slice (slice 18). The T1-weighted image and the functional images were coregistered to Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) space, after which the T1-weighted image was coregistered to the functional images. Subsequently, the T1-weighted images were segmented into gray matter, white matter, and CSF.
To achieve more accurate spatial normalization given the clinical nature of the patient group, the fMRI time series was normalized and smoothed using a study-specific template. The fMRI time series was then transformed and resampled at an isotropic voxel size of 2 mm, resulting in spatially normalized, Jacobian scaled, and smoothed (8 mm FWHM Gaussian kernel) images in (MNI) space.

Multiple regression
First level analyses: The fMRI time series will be analyzed in an event-related design within the general linear model. We will model two regressors of interest describing the onset and duration of each cue condition (actual, opposite) and four regressors of interest describing the onset and duration of each target condition (actual-happy, actual-sad, opposite-happy, opposite-sad) as separate boxcar functions convolved with the canonical hemodynamic response function. Time responses of button presses convolved with the canonical hemodynamic response function and head movement parameters (3 translations, 3 rotations) will be added to the model as regressors of no interest as well as the squared, cubic, first-order, and second-order derivatives of the movement parameters. Furthermore, incorrect responses will be modelled as an additional regressor. Finally, time courses of signal intensities of white matter, CSF, and the portion of the MR image outside the skull will also be included as three additional regressors. 

The fMRI time series will be high-pass filtered (128 s cutoff), and a first-order autoregressive model will be used to account for temporal autocorrelation. Contrast images of the effects of interest (actual-happy, actual-sad, opposite-happy, opposite-sad) will be generated per subject and entered into a random-effects multiple regression second level analysis. 

Therefore, we will test for an emotion inhibition effect (opposite vs. actual) in each group (controls and remitted MDD patients (relapse and non-relapse)), separately for each valence (happy and sad). This results in the following contrasts: [opposite-sad vs. actual-sad] and [opposite-happy vs. actual-happy]. With the general linear model, we will compare the emotion inhibition effects between groups. Furthermore, we will exploratorily investigate whether brooding differentially modulates the emotion inhibition effect of each valence and in each group. In addition to the whole-brain analyses, we will test for emotion inhibition effects within the dlPFC, ACC, and amygdala. In a second step, in order to investigate whether brooding scores interact with the aforementioned effects, we will include brooding scores to the model as a covariate of interest as subject, group and condition-specific covariates. We will also include a sensitivity analysis to confirm that the results still hold after taking baseline HDRS scores into account. Finally, it is important to note that not all participants completed the same amount of blocks of CECT trials (either four (n = 2), five (n = 23), or six (n = 76)). Therefore, a post hoc sensitivity analysis will be conducted to check whether there is a difference between the participants that completed five blocks and the participants that completed six blocks. 

 
Predicting recurrence
To predict the recurrence of a depressive episode, we will first run separate univariate cox regressions on RT, age, sex, number of previous depressive episodes, baseline HDRS scores, and rumination score. fMRI contrast images of the effects of interest (created per subject from the first-level model) and statistically significant factors (from the univariate regressions) will be entered into Neuropointillist (http://ibic.github.io/neuropointillist) for a whole brain (voxel-by-voxel) multivariate cox regression model. We will specifically test effects in predefined ROIs (dlPFC, dACC, vACC, amygdala), followed by a more exploratory whole brain analysis. Statistical inference will be done with AFNI’s 3dClustSim to determine the cluster extent based on the spatial structure of the noise in the dataset using the auto-correlation function (ACF) parameters obtained from the residual timeseries.
registration_responses.q19: For the behavioural analysis, confidence intervals will be used to determine significant effects. Regarding the neural analyses, we will use p<.05 to determine significant effects. Family-wise error (FWE) correction will be applied to neuroimaging data to correct for multiple comparisons. For ROI analyses, a small volume correction will be performed.
registration_responses.q20:
Participants with poor quality of MRI data (e.g. artefacts, excessive signal drop-out or movement) will be excluded. For behavioural data, subjects with an overall accuracy of 50% and below will be excluded. Furthermore, outliers, identified as more than 3.5 standard deviations from the participants’ mean response time per condition, will also be excluded. 

We will also check (and exclude) outliers using Mahalanobis distance for mean response times per condition and questionnaire data taken together.
registration_responses.q21: Participants with no data on the RRS-NL will be excluded from the analyses on brooding scores. Furthermore, if information about a possible recurrence during the follow-up period is missing, that participant will be excluded from any analysis comparing the relapse and the non-relapse patient groups.
registration_responses.q23:

attributes.title: Use expectancies and experienced gratification and compensation in social networks use disorder and tobacco use disorder
attributes.description:
Problematic use of social networks is increasingly discussed as another specific form of Internet-associated behavioral addictions (Wegmann et al., 2018). Use expectancies refer to subjective thoughts regarding concrete effects of drug intake or a specific behavior; and have already been identified as relevant factor in tobacco use disorder (Abrams et al., 2011) and social network use disorder (SNUD; Wegmann et al., 2015). Furthermore, it is assumed that positive reinforcement mechanisms (i.e., experiences of gratification, rewarding experiences) play a crucial role in symptoms of SNUD. By contrast, negative reinforcement and compensation-seeking mechanisms (i.e., reduction of the fear of isolation and fear of missing out) are relevant for a “fear-driven” approach (Wegmann & Brand, 2019). However, it remains unclear whether the use of social network applications can indeed gratify usage motives or compensate unsatisfied needs, and whether this affects future use expectancies.

Against this background, the approach to track behavior in daily life is especially promising; it avoids recall bias, opens the stage for sophisticated analyses of specific behavioral patterns (Montag et al., 2016), and might provide the possibility to assess cognitive tendencies such as use expectancies and experienced gratification or compensation of (formerly) unsatisfied needs immediately after using social networks applications.

The aim of this project is to investigate and compare the relevance of specific use expectancies as well as gratification and compensation experiences in SNUD and tobacco use disorder.

For this purpose, subjects will be divided into four groups based on standardized tests and interviews: Subjects with 1) SNUD, 2) risky social networks use, 3) unproblematic use, and 4) tobacco use disorder. These participants complete a two-week smartphone-based survey using the experience sampling method.

It es expected that the results acquired from this study will help to confirm the findings of the I-PACE model (Brand et al., 2019) which suggests that use expectancies and gratification play an active part in triggerring and maintaining Internet use disorders.

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1.1a (directional): Positive use expectations related to social networks use are detectable in social networks use disorder and are related to symptom severity. Individuals with social network use disorder will show higher positive use expectations for social network use compared to risky users, healthy controls, and individuals with tobacco use disorder. Positive use expectancies will be higher among risky social network users than healthy controls.

Hypotheses 1.2b: Positive use expectancies related to tobacco use are related to symptom severity of tobacco use disorder. Individuals with tobacco use disorder will experience higher positive use expectancies when smoking than individuals without smoking behavior.

Hypothesis 1.2a (directional): Negative reinforcement expectancies related to social networks use are detectable in social network use disorder and are related to symptom severity. Individuals with social networks use disorder will show higher negative reinforcement expectancies when using social networks compared to risky users, healthy controls, and individuals with tobacco use disorder. Negative use expectancies are higher among risky social network users* than healthy controls.

Hypotheses 1.2b: Negative reinforcement expectancies related to tobacco use are related to symptom severity of tobacco use disorder. Individuals with tobacco use disorder will experience higher negative reinforcement expectancies when smoking than individuals without smoking behavior.

Hypothesis 2.1a (directional): The experience of gratification related to social networks use is demonstrable in social networks use disorder and is related to symptom severity. Individuals with social networks use disorder will experience higher reward of specific needs and motives when using social networks than risky users, healthy controls, and individuals with tobacco use disorder.

Hypotheses 2.1b: The experience of gratification related to tobacco use is related to symptom severity of tobacco use disorder. Individuals with tobacco use disorder will experience higher reward when smoking than individuals without smoking behavior.

Hypothesis 2.2a: The experience of compensation related to social networks use is detectable in social networks use disorder and is related to symptom severity. Individuals with social networks use disorder will experience higher compensation for unmet needs and deficits in social networks use compared to risky users, healthy controls, and individuals with tobacco use disorder.

Hypotheses 2.2b: The experience of compensation related to tobacco use is related to symptom severity of tobacco use disorder. Individuals with tobacco use disorder will experience higher compensation when smoking than individuals without smoking behavior.

The effect of specific use expectancies and experienced gratification and compensation for social networks use disorder and tobacco use disorder will be compared. The highest effects are expected for the specific cognitive tendencies (i.e., use expectancies, gratification and compensation) and associated behavior. 

Furthermore, due to the study design, we will examine to what extent the specific use expectancies (social networks and tobacco use) as well as the specific experience of gratification and compensation for the social networks users and individuals with tobacco use disorder evolve over the course of the day. Here, we examine whether there are differences between and within the groups over the course of the day.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will use a mixed-methods, cross-sectional, between-subjects design with four groups (see below). In addition, the concept of smartphone tracking as a form of 14-day ambulatory assessment also allows for repeated measurements (within-subject). This means that the assessment of use expectations, and the gratification and compensation experienced will be done over all days and several times during a day.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Subjects are recruited via promotional activities, such as flyers, notices, or advertisements at the survey sites at the University of Lübeck and University of Duisburg-Essen. Furthermore, based on microtargeting techniques, the subjects are specifically addressed when using the Internet and referred to the website for prescreening.

The smartphone app-based Ambulatory Assessment will be started after subjects have completed the laboratory assessment (which is described in other parts of the project). 
After obtaining informed consent, participants receive a payment of €5 for each day they participate fully and without interruptions in the smartphone assessment, resulting in a maximum possible amount of €70 for the two-week survey period.

Inclusion criteria for all groups are age ≥ 16 and ≤ 65 years and sufficient knowledge of German. Exclusion criteria for all groups are learning or developmental disorders, psychosis, mania, current substance use disorder (besides tobacco use), acute suicidal ideation, and use of psychoactive substances that impair performanc

q11.value:
Participants are divided into four groups. Of these, three groups include individuals who have developed pathological or problematic behavior: Individuals with (1) social network use disorder without tobacco use, (2) risky social network use patterns without tobacco use, and (3) tobacco use disorder without pathological or problematic social network use. In addition, a control group matched for age, sex, and education (4) who neither smoked nor had problems with social network use was recruited. 

We aim for a sample size of N=204, evenly distributed among all four subgroups (for each group n = 51, 50% women)

q12.value: The targeted sample size results from a power analysis performed using G*Power (3.1.9.2) for the main research questions of the laboratory study (which is described elsewhere).

question.value:
Problematic social network use / SNUD:
Problematic social network use is assessed using an adapted, project-specific version of the Structured Clinical Interview on Internet-related disorders (AICA-SKI:IBS; Müller et al., 2017), which is based on the DSM-V criteria for Internet Gaming Disorder. Subjects who meet at least one of the nine criteria mentioned are assigned to the group of risky users. Subjects who fulfill five or more criteria are assigned to the group of pathological users (SNUD).

Tobacco use/tobacco use disorder:
We will use the Fagerström Test for Nicotine Dependence (Heatherton et al., 1991)wich is a widely used standard tool. Based on a latent class analysis, a score of less than 4 is considered non-addictive use (Agrawal et al, 2011). In addition, participants will be asked if they had smoked at least one cigarette per day. 

Use expectancies, gratification and compensation:
Use expectancies as well as gratification and compensation experience will be recorded using a smartphone app developed specifically for this project. For this purpose, subjects are notified three times a day (every five hours starting at 07:00) via push notification and asked to provide information within the app. For this, the gratification and/or compensation experience for the past five hours is queried. The query of the use expectancies is directional into the future and is asked in relation to the next exercise of the addictive behavior. Subjects rate all items on visual analog scales from 1 to 10.Detailed information on individual items and their wording can be found in the attached smartphone tracking document.

Data on the specific use expectancies (related to social networks use and tobacco use), and the specific experiences of gratification and/or compensation (related to social networks use and tobacco use) will be analyzed using pairwise comparisons between the individuals with social networks use disorder and one of the three other groups (individuals with tobacco-use disorder, individuals with risky use of social networks, healthy controls), and between individuals with tobacco use disorder and individuals without smoking behavior, respectively. 

In addition, the effect sizes of the specific cognitive tendencies (use expectancies, gratification, and compensation) and the associated behavior are compared with each other. 

Multiple regression analyses, analyses of variance with repeated measures and multilevel analyses will be used to examine use expectancies and experienced gratification and compensation over the course of a day but also the 14-day ambulatory assessment within as well as between groups.

q20.value:
Careless responder analyses will be done as recommended by Curran (2016;) and Meade and Craig (2012). This will include inspection of awareness checks, response times for the questionnaire blocks; long-string analysis, Mahalanobis-distance, even-odd analysis. 

Individuals identified with one of these methods will be inspected by the authors. 
Individuals who do not meet inclusion/exclusion criteria (after the experimental data has been collected e.g., due to new medication that has been taken after the screening procedure) will be excluded

Outlier identified via 2 SD deviating from the mean on multiple scores will be inspected by the authors.

q21.value: If hypotheses cannot be tested with the existing data due to missing data, we plan to aggregate groups and use a dimensional approach.

q23.value:
The study registered here is based on data from the subproject "Implicit associations, use expectations and gratification in social network use disorder and tobacco use disorder (FOR 2974/ RP8)" which in turn is part of the multicenter research project "Affective and cognitive mechanisms of specific Internet-use disorders (ACSID)".

Literature:

Agrawal, A., Scherrer, J. F., Pergadia, M. L., Lynskey, M. T., Madden, P. A. F., Sartor, C. E., … Xian, H. (2011). A latent class analysis of DSM-IV and Fagerström (FTND) Criteria for Nicotine Dependence. Nicotine & Tobacco Research, 13(10), 972–981. https://doi.org/10.1093/NTR/NTR105

Neuroscience & Biobehavioral Reviews, 104, 1–10. https://doi.org/10.1016/J.NEUBIOREV.2019.06.032

Meade, A. W., & Craig, S. B. (2012). Identifying careless responses in survey data. Psychological Methods, 17(3), 437–455. https://doi.org/10.1037/A0028085

Müller, K., Beutel, M., & Wölfling, K. (2017). Klinische Validierung von diagnostischen Merkmalen der Internetsucht. Suchttherapie, 18(1), 10-12. https://doi.org/10.1055/S-0037-1604540

Wegmann, E., & Brand, M. (2019). A narrative overview about psychosocial characteristics as risk factors of a problematic social networks use. Current Addiction Reports, 6(4), 402–409. https://doi.org/10.1007/S40429-019-00286-8

Wegmann, E., Stodt, B., & Brand, M. (2015). Addictive use of social networking sites can be explained by the interaction of Internet use expectancies, Internet literacy, and psychopathological symptoms. Journal of Behavioral Addictions, 4(3), 155–162. https://doi.org/10.1556/2006.4.2015.021
