After obtaining informed consent, participants receive a payment of €5 for each day they participate fully and without interruptions in the smartphone assessment, resulting in a maximum possible amount of €70 for the two-week survey period.

Inclusion criteria for all groups are age ≥ 16 and ≤ 65 years and sufficient knowledge of German. Exclusion criteria for all groups are learning or developmental disorders, psychosis, mania, current substance use disorder (besides tobacco use), acute suicidal ideation, and use of psychoactive substances that impair performanc
registration_responses.q11:
Participants are divided into four groups. Of these, three groups include individuals who have developed pathological or problematic behavior: Individuals with (1) social network use disorder without tobacco use, (2) risky social network use patterns without tobacco use, and (3) tobacco use disorder without pathological or problematic social network use. In addition, a control group matched for age, sex, and education (4) who neither smoked nor had problems with social network use was recruited. 

We aim for a sample size of N=204, evenly distributed among all four subgroups (for each group n = 51, 50% women)
registration_responses.q12: The targeted sample size results from a power analysis performed using G*Power (3.1.9.2) for the main research questions of the laboratory study (which is described elsewhere).
registration_responses.q15.question:
Problematic social network use / SNUD:
Problematic social network use is assessed using an adapted, project-specific version of the Structured Clinical Interview on Internet-related disorders (AICA-SKI:IBS; Müller et al., 2017), which is based on the DSM-V criteria for Internet Gaming Disorder. Subjects who meet at least one of the nine criteria mentioned are assigned to the group of risky users. Subjects who fulfill five or more criteria are assigned to the group of pathological users (SNUD).

Tobacco use/tobacco use disorder:
We will use the Fagerström Test for Nicotine Dependence (Heatherton et al., 1991)wich is a widely used standard tool. Based on a latent class analysis, a score of less than 4 is considered non-addictive use (Agrawal et al, 2011). In addition, participants will be asked if they had smoked at least one cigarette per day. 

Use expectancies, gratification and compensation:
Use expectancies as well as gratification and compensation experience will be recorded using a smartphone app developed specifically for this project. For this purpose, subjects are notified three times a day (every five hours starting at 07:00) via push notification and asked to provide information within the app. For this, the gratification and/or compensation experience for the past five hours is queried. The query of the use expectancies is directional into the future and is asked in relation to the next exercise of the addictive behavior. Subjects rate all items on visual analog scales from 1 to 10.Detailed information on individual items and their wording can be found in the attached smartphone tracking document.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Data on the specific use expectancies (related to social networks use and tobacco use), and the specific experiences of gratification and/or compensation (related to social networks use and tobacco use) will be analyzed using pairwise comparisons between the individuals with social networks use disorder and one of the three other groups (individuals with tobacco-use disorder, individuals with risky use of social networks, healthy controls), and between individuals with tobacco use disorder and individuals without smoking behavior, respectively. 

In addition, the effect sizes of the specific cognitive tendencies (use expectancies, gratification, and compensation) and the associated behavior are compared with each other. 

Multiple regression analyses, analyses of variance with repeated measures and multilevel analyses will be used to examine use expectancies and experienced gratification and compensation over the course of a day but also the 14-day ambulatory assessment within as well as between groups.
registration_responses.q20:
Careless responder analyses will be done as recommended by Curran (2016;) and Meade and Craig (2012). This will include inspection of awareness checks, response times for the questionnaire blocks; long-string analysis, Mahalanobis-distance, even-odd analysis. 

Individuals identified with one of these methods will be inspected by the authors. 
Individuals who do not meet inclusion/exclusion criteria (after the experimental data has been collected e.g., due to new medication that has been taken after the screening procedure) will be excluded

Outlier identified via 2 SD deviating from the mean on multiple scores will be inspected by the authors.
registration_responses.q21: If hypotheses cannot be tested with the existing data due to missing data, we plan to aggregate groups and use a dimensional approach.
registration_responses.q23:
The study registered here is based on data from the subproject "Implicit associations, use expectations and gratification in social network use disorder and tobacco use disorder (FOR 2974/ RP8)" which in turn is part of the multicenter research project "Affective and cognitive mechanisms of specific Internet-use disorders (ACSID)".

attributes.title: Implicit cognitions, use expectancies, and gratification in social-networks-use disorder and tobacco use disorder (FOR 2974/RP8)
attributes.description:
Social networks like Facebook or Instagram are widely used. With the inclusion of gaming disorder in the ICD-11 as a disorder due to addictive behaviors, the problematic use of social networks is discussed as one further specific type of Internet use disorders. The I-PACE (Interaction of Person-Affect-Cognition-Execution) model provides a theoretical framework describing key concepts and their interactions likely involved in the development and maintenance of addictive behaviors. Implicit cognitions such as implicit associations linked to automatic processing and approach tendencies may override the control system by exacerbating goal-directed inhibitory processes. Use expectancies refer to subjective thoughts regarding concrete effects of drug intake or of a specific behavior. These expectancies might be experienced explicitly or implicitly and are likely based on underlying cognitive processes. After experiencing positive outcomes, this could result in positive (implicit) associations and in the experience of gratification and compensation of subjective needs. Studies have already demonstrated the relevance of implicit cognitions in substance-use disorders (e.g., tobacco-use disorder), as well as in gaming disorder and pornography-use disorder. However, studies investigating implicit cognitions in social-networks-use disorder are lacking. Furthermore, there is empirical evidence underlining the relevance of use expectancies in tobacco-use disorder and social-networks-use disorder, but no research has investigated potential interactions with implicit cognitions and the experience of gratification and/or compensation. This project aims at investigating the relevance of 1) implicit cognitions upon confrontation with addiction-related stimuli, 2) the experiences of gratification and compensation when using online social networks, and 3) use expectancies in social-networks-use disorder and tobacco-use disorder. It will be the first to compare individuals with social-networks-use disorder and individuals with tobacco-use disorder. The project will include four groups: individuals with 1) social-networks-use disorder, 2) risky use of social networks, 3) non-problematic use of social networks, and 4) tobacco-use disorder. Besides the surveys and structured interviews for the diagnostics and the experimental and neuropsychological tasks of the core battery, an Implicit Association Test with addiction-related stimuli and an online application for data-tracking assessing gratification and compensation within the two weeks after assessment will be administered. 
This project is part of the research group FOR 2974. See project (ACSID) and ACSID Homepage: https://www.uni-due.de/for2974/index.php

attributes.title: Thought Shape Fusion in a Residential Eating Disorder Sample
attributes.description: Examination of the thought shape fusion questionnaire's psychometric properties in a residential clinical sample.

q2.value:
The theorized two-factor model of the 18-item Thought Shape Fusion questionnaire will meet at least adequate fit criteria when subjected to a confirmatory factor analysis using a clinical sample.
Model fit will be at least adequate for adults and adolescents.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Confirmatory factor analysis of combined adult and adolescent clinical sample. Followed by a confirmatory factor analysis of adult and adolescent groups individually. If fit is poor an exploratory factor analysis will be performed to further assess the factor structure in a clinical sample.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: Data has already been collected. The sample includes adult and adolescent patients at a residential eating disorder treatment facility. All patient data will be included in the analysis.

q12.value: We will be using all available data that was collected for the facility from clients at intake.

question.value: Not applicable

Main outcome variable of interest is the Thought Shape Fusion Questionnaire. The main purpose of the study is to examine the factor structure and other psychometric properties of the measure.

Other measures used to examine construct validity:
Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire - All four subscales
Beck Depression Inventory - Total score
Beck Anxiety Inventory - Total score
Body Image Acceptance and Action Questionnaire - 11-item version total score that removes item six as recommended by Lee et al., 2017.
Cognitive Fusion Questionnaire - Body Image - Total score
Self-Compassion Scale - All six subscales

Univariate coefficients of skewness and kurtosis will be used to assess the assumption of normality for the Thought Shape Fusion Questionnaire data (using the R MVN package). Values of skewness < |2| and kurtosis < |7|will be used to indicate data appropriate for ML model estimation.
 
T-test will be used to compared potential differences between adolescents and adults for all variables.

A confirmatory factor analysis will examine the two factor structure of the Thought Shape Fusion Questionnaire proposed by Coelho et al., 2013 (i.e., factor 1 = items 1-14; factor 2 = items 15-18). 

If CFA indicates poor model fit we will perform an exploratory factor analysis to examine the factor structure of the Thought Shape Fusion Questionnaire in this clinical population. Assuming normality of data, we will use an ML factor extraction method. A direct oblimin oblique rotation method will be used. Eigenvalues (roughly greater than 1) and a scree test will be used to explore how many factors to retain. The "cleanest" factor structure will be retained (i.e., item loadings above .30, few cross loadings between items).

If a factor structure that differs from the original is suggested by the EFA, an additional CFA will be performed. The original model and new model will be compared to assess whether the new model performs statistically significantly better. The model comparison will use methods recommended by Schermelleh-Engel et al. 2003 to assess differences in chi-square values and degrees of freedom. A p-value < .05 will be used to determine whether the new model fit the data significantly better than the old one.

Pearsons correlations will be performed between the Thought Shape Fusion Questionnaire and all variables of interest to assess convergent and discriminant validity.

Cronbach's alpha will be calculated to assess for internal reliability.

q18.value: No data transformations or recoding are planned.

q19.value:
Two-tailed t-tests between adolescents and adults will use a False Discovery Rate (FDR) corrected p-value to determine significance.

CFA model fit will be assessed using the relative/normed chi-square statistic. Ratios below 2 will be good fit. Ratios below 5 will be considered acceptable fit. Other fit indices used will include: RMSEA <= .08 considered acceptable, SRMR <= .05 considered good <= .08 considered acceptable, CFI >= .95.

If an EFA is used, factor loadings greater than or equal to .50 without secondly loadings greater than .30 will be considered to be well performing.

Pearsons correlations between the Thought Shape Fusion Questionnaire and all other total scores and subscales will use a p-value of < .05 to determine significance.

q20.value:
Participants who answered with the same response on 20 or more consecutive items of the assessment battery were excluded for careless responding.

Participants who did not complete at least 80% of any given measures or subscale will be excluded.

Any outliers will included in the analysis.

q21.value: Missing values will be imputed using predictive mean matching and multiple imputations with the R (mice) function.
